awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Solving the bait learning problem for large-scale DNA enrichment
awd_abstract_narration:
The microbiome refers to all micro-organisms within a biological sample and has been linked to numerous biological activities and phenotypes.  For example, the “gut microbiome”, which commonly refers to the bacteria found within the digestive system in humans, has been attributed to countless phenotypes and diseases, including obesity, Alzheimer’s disease, autism spectrum disorder, and types of cancer.  Similarly, the soil microbiome has been attributed to drought tolerance, flowering time, and pesticide resistance in plants.  Comprehensively studying the micro-organisms in a biological sample is challenging as that it is estimated that between 95% and 99% of them cannot live outside their natural environments, and therefore, cannot be isolated in a laboratory environment.  Fortunately, shotgun metagenomics can address this challenge since it is able to take as input the DNA corresponding to all the micro-organisms within a sample and produce the DNA strings (which are called “sequence reads”) corresponding to them.  These sequencer reads are then further analyzed to identify and study the micro-organisms.  However, frequently scientists are interested in studying a limited number of micro-organisms rather than all of them.  For example, in the case of studying the micro-organisms from a respiratory swab, it may be the case that only the sequence reads corresponding to COVID-19 are of interest.  Shotgun metagenomics will produce sequence reads for all DNA found on the swab.  Fortunately, there are laboratory methods capable of restricting the sequencing to only a selected set of DNA sequences, which is referred to as DNA enrichment.  DNA enrichment creates and applies a set of short, synthetic DNA fragments (called “baits”) to a biological sample which then bind to only selected portions of the DNA.  The unbound DNA is then rinsed away, leaving only the bound DNA that is then sequenced.  Hence, the first step of this process is the informatics problem of identifying the baits that will enrich for a given set of DNA sequences.  Two things that make the informatics problem challenging is that the number of baits should be of minimum size, and the baits do not only bind exactly to a single DNA sequence, but they can bind to many sequences with some allowable mismatches.  This project will devise we will combine techniques in informatics, machine learning and data integration techniques to create practical methods for creating baits. 
 
While existing heuristics demonstrated the utility of DNA enrichment, there still does not exist any methods that are able to do this efficiently for large DNA databases.  Hence, one of the focuses of this project is to create scalable methods.  To accomplish this, we will develop methods for solving two different informatics problems: (1) the Bait Minimization problem that aims to identify the set of baits of minimal size that enrich for the entire set of DNA sequences, and (2) the DNA Sequence Maximization problem which aims to select the largest subset of DNA sequences that can be enriched by using a bait set of restricted size. Here, we will integrate the information of the biological process into the problem formulations and solve the problems using state-of-the-art informatic approaches. This project will result in several innovations that will have major impact in informatics, data science and other scientific disciplines. The broader impact of this work will encompass the furtherance of our knowledge micro-organisms and the creation of curriculum for Girls Engaged in Engineering Days at the University of Florida.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to address inefficiencies in sequencing specific DNA sequences, such as antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes or viral strains, within metagenomic datasets. Traditional metagenomic sequencing often results in a large portion of sequence reads being irrelevant to the research question, leading to high costs and reduced sensitivity. Targeted enrichment, which uses biotinylated cDNA bait molecules to capture specific DNA regions, provides a solution by selectively sequencing DNA of interest. This project seeks to solve the computational challenges associated with designing effective bait sets, which include minimizing the number of baits to reduce costs and accommodating mismatches between bait and target DNA sequences.

Aim 1: Create Scalable Methods for Creating Bait Sets

The first aim is to develop practical methods for designing minimal bait sets and scalable methods to enrich the maximum number of sequences with a limited number of baits. The project formalized the Minimum Bait Cover Problem and proved its computational complexity. This problem involves determining the smallest possible set of baits that cover all positions in a set of DNA sequences, considering allowable mismatches.

Aim 2: Develop Methods to Disseminate and Maintain Baits

The second aim focuses on disseminating the source code and informatic tools and publicly releasing several bait sets for important DNA databases. The project plans to develop scalable methods to update bait sets with new sequences and release baits for all reference strains of SARS-COV-2 and common human viruses. 

Significant Results and Accomplishments

  1. Formalization and Complexity Analysis: The project formalized the Minimum Bait Cover Problem and proved its NP-hardness, even for extremely restrictive versions. This significant theoretical result establishes the foundational difficulty of the problem, guiding the development of heuristic solutions.

  2. Development of Syotti: The project developed Syotti, an efficient heuristic based on the FM-index, capable of scaling to large sets of sequences. Syotti outperformed competing methods in terms of speed and the number of baits produced, making it a practical tool for designing bait sets. This method demonstrated its scalability and efficiency in processing large datasets of AMR genes, bacterial genomes, and viral genomes.

  3. Comparison with Competing Methods: Syotti was rigorously compared with MrBait and CATCH across different datasets. While MrBait processed all datasets, it was significantly slower and produced an impractically large number of baits. CATCH failed to process larger datasets within a reasonable timeframe. Syotti, on the other hand, managed to process all datasets efficiently, highlighting its practical applicability and superiority over existing methods.

  4. Coverage Evaluation: The coverage of genomes with bait sets produced by Syotti was evaluated, showing that it achieved 100% coverage on the MEGARes dataset and significantly better coverage on bacterial and viral genomes compared to MrBait and CATCH. Syotti's ability to achieve high coverage with fewer baits underscores its efficiency and effectiveness.

  5. Development of TELSeq and TELSVirus: The project developed TELSeq, a method for capturing long DNA fragments and generating enriched long-read sequence data, and TELSVirus, an adaptation for enriching multiple viral genomes simultaneously. TELSeq demonstrated high sensitivity in detecting low-abundance ARGs from complex matrices, providing robust colocalization of ARGs with nearby MGEs. TELSVirus showed superior sensitivity and specificity in detecting multiple viral genomes from complex samples, often outperforming rRT-PCR.

  6. Publications and Presentations: The results of the project have been disseminated through publications and presentations. The findings were published in the Journal of Bioinformatics (Special issue of ISMB 2022) and presented at ISMB 2022. Additional papers are in submission, including one on TELSVirus to Molecular Biology Resources and another on TELSeq to Genome Research. These publications and presentations have contributed to the broader scientific community's understanding of the project's advancements.

  7. Application to Agricultural Data: The project applied TELSeq to agricultural data to understand how the microbiome and resistome are affected by activities on a commercial farm. This study, currently in submission to Science and the Total Environment, demonstrated TELSeq's ability to profile the microbiome and resistome changes throughout the workday of agricultural workers, highlighting its potential for practical applications in agricultural and environmental microbiology.

  8. Protocols and Methodological Papers: The project has prepared several papers detailing the protocols and methodologies developed, including a systematic study of the sensitivity and specificity of enrichment methods. These papers, in submission to Current Protocols and Genome Research, provide comprehensive guidelines and insights into the use of TELSeq and related techniques, supporting their adoption and further development by the scientific community.

Overall, the project's results and accomplishments have significantly advanced the field of targeted DNA sequencing, providing scalable and efficient methods for designing bait sets, enhancing the detection and characterization of specific DNA sequences, and contributing to global efforts to combat antimicrobial resistance and improve viral diagnostics and surveillance.
